events.target_title: At startup, GIMP crashes with fatal error: unhandled exception
At startup, GIMP crashes with fatal error: unhandled exception
make[2]: *** No rule to make target '../pango/libpangocairo-1.0.la', needed by 'markup-parse'.  Stop.

note.body:
I got same error on my machine.
I found the reason to be compiling it for 32bit architecture on 64bit machine.
cairo library was only available for the 64bit version so it caused both the missing cairo.h error and the No rule to make target '../pango/libpangocairo-1.0.la' error.

I've recompiled mesa for 32bit and the problem was resolved.

events.target_title: WIP: clutter/stage: Process input events out of phase with redraws [performance]

note.body:
I am not a fan of this either. Chrome coalesces input events and it just causes so many issues, such as missing frame presentation after moving the mouse, and severely degrading remote input (Remotedesktop, TeamViewer, VNC, etc).

Why not just deliver the events especially mouse movement events as they are?  Just delay drawing anything until a few milliseconds before the next vblank. 

The CPU usage increase is not a serious argument its like an extra 1%~ with a 500hz mouse. If your wastefully drawing as a response to every mousemove, then indeed that will eat a lot of cycles, so dont draw.

note.body: Ended up running a bisect anyway, first bad commit is apparently 46355341dd69b693f83f6bc0dfa1587cbe0abbd1

events.target_title: crash with master branch

note.body:
If I revert only that commit, I end up with a slightly different error:
```
/home/j3tracey/Documents/meld/meld/ui/_gtktemplate.py:113: Warning: g_object_ref_sink: assertion 'object->ref_count >= 1' failed
  base_init_template(self)
**
ERROR:../../gi/pygobject-object.c:690:pygobject_register_wrapper: assertion failed: (gself->obj->ref_count >= 1)
```
the python backtrace is the same as before, but the C backtrace is also slightly different in thread 1 (frame `#8` here is frame `#4` in the other trace):

events.target_title: gnome-keyring-daemon intermittently fails under KDE (X)
gnome-keyring-daemon intermittently fails under KDE (X)

note.body:
Perhaps, but it might be a good idea to verify that you have everything set up correctly. You will need to configure /etc/pam.d/sddm (assuming you are using SDDM) to unlock the gnome-keyring.  Also, you will need to remove (I think) the "Default" keyring and set "login" as default.  Your account password and the password for the keyring will need to be the same.  I'm not sure what distribution you are using, but the Arch documentation isn't bad: https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/GNOME/Keyring.

For the original bug submitted, it seems more like gnome-keyring-daemon simply crashes on boot.  Once it is restarted, it tends to work okay.

events.target_title: renderer/native: add missing eglTerminate in EGLDevice error path

note.body:
Thanks for checking @xexaxo. @fmuellner For context I ran into this issue trying to (at long last) achieve freesync with amdgpu. Considering it's the most recent Ubuntu LTS desktop release it will have a substantial userbase. But it's not broken as distributed, because the mentioned Mesa commit hasn't landed there.

The problem occurs when moving to a newer graphics stack from PPAs like https://launchpad.net/~oibaf/+archive/ubuntu/graphics-drivers or https://launchpad.net/~paulo-miguel-dias/+archive/ubuntu/mesa

I haven't found a well packaged way to upgrade gnome/mutter, so my options were basically switching distro, reverting to the older drivers, or disable wayland in the gdm3 settings (which is what I settled for).

I would completely understand if this won't land on earlier version. In the end you can't expect manually installing 5.0 kernels and 3rd party packaged graphics drivers to retain that LTS level of polish. But I think there's a fair chance more Ubuntu amdgpu gamers that won't speak up will avoid gnome on wayland for this reason.

events.target_title: renderer/native: add missing eglTerminate in EGLDevice error path

note.body:
I understand, and completely fair :+1: @fmuellner 
My intention was to add context to why I suggested it.

events.target_title: renderer/native: add missing eglTerminate in EGLDevice error path

note.body:
Ah, thank you that's good news.

I won't pretend to have a clue about the specifics of either fix, so when it comes to nominations I'll defer to the experts. I had assumed this was purely a mutter issue highlighted by a change in mesa and wasn't expecting a fix on both sides.

If the mesa fix alone can resolve https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=110903 I should be ok with 3.28 mutter and a mesa packaged from master in the next few hours or days.

events.target_title: Proprietary NVIDIA driver issues: GNOME random freezing

note.body:
Can confirm it happens on Ubuntu 19.04, GNOME 3.32.1, NVIDIA GTX 1050 as primary card with NVIDIA Prime.

This bug is mainly noticeable when using drag 'n' drop functionalities in any application (GNOME Shell window dragging, Nautilus file dragging, Spotify music dragging, Chrome link dragging, etc).

**Edit:** Can also confirm that setting `__GL_MaxFramesAllowed=1` globally makes the freezes go away completely, although I don't think that's an ideal solution since it seems to degrade performance.

note.body:
Apparently this  is well known by the rest of the industry and just read a
review comparing GIMP to photoshop that pointed out that this is a serious
limitation making GIMP useless for professional printing.   To make it
worse, the 3d color printers that are  hitting the market this year all use
CMYK ink and THEY cant use GIMP either for the same limitation.

In CMYK 255,255,255,0 is equal to BLACK as is 0,0,0,255!  adding black ink
to any color in a 3d print totally ruins the print and DOES NOT just make
it  grey.

events.target_title: Super+number key combos can't be overriden in GNOME 3.32

note.body:
I was also struggling to get my keybindings to work until finding this issue and gsettings.
Managed to remove default bindings with the following command (use at your own risk):

`for i in {1..9}; do gsettings set "org.gnome.shell.keybindings" "switch-to-application-$i" "[]"; done`

Either way would be much better to have these bindings shown (or at least allow override) in _keyboard settings_.

events.target_title: Crash during drag-and-drop in flowbox in debug mode
Provide "diff" option to highlight any changes when closing an unsaved document
Provide "diff" option to highlight any changes when closing an unsaved document

note.body:
Thanks for your response Andre. 
Yes - this could be achieved with diff tools like Meld etc. which requires the user to;
1. save the file (under a different name), 
2. open both files with the diff software, 
3. wait for the software to check/display differences, 
4. delete the unwanted file,
5. rename the newly saved file (if the changes are to be kept).
This process can take quite a while when there are lots of files involved. 

The feature suggestion is mostly about delivering more power (convenience/efficiency) to the user intuitively (ie. without requiring them to learn a new process/key-combination/etc..). The objective of the feature is to assist the user to decide whether the changes are significant (save) or trivial (discard). I was thinking of a simple 'highlighting the things that have changed' type behavior. I am not suggesting to re-invent the wheel by implementing a fully featured 'diff' type function. (If it is that involved, then forget it!) 

I am presuming the unsaved changes are stored in some memory buffer (eg. which can be accessed by the 'undo' function) so that highlighting changed regions would be a fairly simple exercise. However, I am also aware my presumptions may be incorrect and happily defer to those more experienced in gedit's implementation details.

The next time you are faced with the 'Save changes before closing?' dialog and you cannot quite remember what the changes were, imagine having a 'Highlight Changes' button :-)

events.target_title: Rename files in folder comparison

note.body:
How about adding an explicit mapping between file names? This could work similar to the synchronization points for file comparisons, just in the context of folders: simply select one file on each pane instead of doing a name-based matching.

I realize this is somewhat different from the file based use case since the order could differ between the two panes. A visual representation of the mapping might be necessary or else it may get too confusing with many files.

events.target_title: Comment field: only one line visible and not resizeable

note.body:
The comment field can be enlarged by adding the following property to the `GtkScrolledWindow` which contains the `song_info_comment` element in data/ui/song-info.ui:
```
                <property name="min-content-height">100</property>
```
I'm not familiar with the RhythmBox code base so I'm not sure if implementing this change creates any problems. At least, this works for me locally: [enlarge_comment_field.diff](/uploads/a92e678c614acff9f7c16607a82486bd/enlarge_comment_field.diff)

events.target_title: Closing displays

note.body:
Hi All,

I have experienced this bug, I regularly use emacs on my laptop remotely when I'm at work and if I pick up my laptop and walk away, I'll get an emacs crash. Quite unfortunate. I've switched to using the emacs-lucid package available in Ubuntu as a work around, but one is left with old-skool scroll bars.

I'm not sure how I can help, other than testing, because I don't have any deep knowledge of the GTK internals. But this seems like something worth resolving, I know users like me are in the long tail, but there is a certain elegance to a library being able to launch and cleanup resources properly, even in complex and hostile cases.


Regards

AK

events.target_title: WIP: Icon Grid ❤ Drag n' Drop

note.body:
Not all folders will contain tools and it would be incorrect to call a folder containing Lollypop, Gnome Music and Spotify as “tools”. In iPhone, when one drags-and-drops one app over the other, iOS tries to identify the common nature of those apps and creates a folder named after their nature : for example, the DnD of Shazam over Spotify will create a folder called « Music ». I don’t know if that can currently be easily implementable in Gnome.

In any case, in iOS the user can change the given standard name at any time.

I should point out that when you create a new folder/file in Files, the latter immediately asks you for a name for it. Thus, in an attempt to be consistent, maybe the DnD of one app over the other should lead to the immediate request of a name for the folder newly created. 

Personally, I am against the Files solution and, therefore, against the implementation of this solution in the AppGrid : since the user can change the name of the file/folder at any time why should the creation of a file/folder depend on a name who may be inadequate or irrelevant in the first place? The more so considering that the content of the file, that is not yet created, may change a lot throughout its existence - requiring therefore the adaptation of its name. A standard automatically given name, even if only “Name1”, would be better in my perspective...

Just my small contribution :s

events.target_title: WIP: Icon Grid ❤ Drag n' Drop

note.body:
Here after, my perspective on this last mockup shared by @jimmac. It is worth what it is :

- the purpose of the AppGrid, and its Pages, is to expose the launchers of all the Apps currently installed in the system - that is, to list all the app launchers, in a continuous way, one by one, one after the other. So it has been in Gnome, so it is in MacOS, in Windows, in Android, in iOS, etc.

- therefore, it is my understanding that the purpose of the AppGrid Pages is NOT and never has been to organise launchers. That purpose belongs to AppFolders - something that already exists in Gnome, as well as in iOS, in Windows, etc.

- Being able to create a second page without having the first completely filled with launchers (i.e. having one Page only with two launchers) adds an unnecessary level of complexity: the User may organise the apps in different Pages that may also contain different Folders containing then different Apps. The Pages become a Super Folder, so to speak, that may lead to extra clicks in order to find and access an app lost in a cascade of folders

- The Pages also lose their initial purpose of exposing the installed apps because the view of the different installed apps will then be disorganised 

- the mockup solution may also comprise another problem. In the right side of the screen, the User will see both the Pages thumbnails when clicking to open the AppGrid and the Workspaces thumbnails when clicking again. In my perspective, this stacking of different thumbnails, for different purposes, in the right side, may be confusing or complex for some people, especially for those less familiar with Gnome or with PCs in general. No OS that I am aware of has anything similar to it...

- Also, contrary to the AppFolders (which have names that suggest their contents), the Pages thumbnails do not have or do not seem to have any name or description

- As a side note, the mockup also does not indicate whether or not the User is going to be able to create AppFolders (and how) and how he is supposed to create/add new (empty) pages to the AppGrid.

Conclusion: unless I understood the mockup completely wrong, I am inclined to not share its view but I rather prefer the one @snwh made - [https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/os-mockups/raw/039c342b1ccf1f970f40bf854b48b2a50d64fcef/app-grid/application-grid-concept.png](https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/os-mockups/raw/039c342b1ccf1f970f40bf854b48b2a50d64fcef/app-grid/application-grid-concept.png). It is also more familiar to what other OS do...

events.target_title: WIP: Icon Grid ❤ Drag n' Drop

note.body:
I agree with this and only with this:

>  Well, if we're talking about efficiency here we could still come to the conclusion that there are (somewhat) more efficient ways:
>  an always-visible panel/taskbar (like Windows)
>  Click On App → App is Open

Thus, the old requests to make an always-visible Dash, as well as the Dash-to-Dock extension (which btw is standard in Ubuntu), and the Dash-to-Panel extension.

I think Gnome devs should take those in consideration and make something of it. Though I understand that they may feel confortable with things as they are or that they do not want to modify much their original creation, I think it would be generally beneficial to offer a dash-to-dock option right in Gnome settings. This would reduce the need to use Gnome Tweak Tool and would give the User more freedom to adapt the OS to its likenesses/needs/preferences. I believe nobody here would argue against people freedoms unless it may harm those of others...

note.body:
Hello everybody,

Our team is using Gnome Software to provide packages and Software to our Linux Population. Unfortunately, users requested a new look for GS.

Our UX Team deployed a CSS file to use with Gnome-Software according users needs, but we don't want to maintain our own gnome-software package. We would like to create a separate package that provides a CSS file. This approach would be perfect to us.

If anyone has any other better idea, feel free to suggest and close this merge request.

Create a bingo / raffle that helps newcomers get to the community

note.body:
Back in 2012 we arranged a "GNOME Mysteries" game targeted at the GSoC and Outreach students. It was more or less a list of "challenges" to get trivia bits to learn about GNOME's history, with an emphasis on interacting with existing community members and providing plenty ice-breaking excuses to meet other people. We also tried to focus on questions/challenges that would lead to anecdotes and stories, helping newcomers get immersed in the GUADEC history/culture/vibe.

https://wiki.gnome.org/Outreach/GnomeMysteries

Regrettably I lost the archive of the produced pictures and videos, but they were real fun and all the teams delivered a bunch of content that we used in the AGM, iirc. This emphasis on media was intentional precisely so that we could have something visual to share and highlight, further immersing them into the community (hopefully).

I randomly stumbled upon this ticket and, FWIW, I thought I'd share this old (very old 👴) bit of history 👀🍄

Not sure if it's the same root cause but I'm also experiencing a time zone related issue with Shotwell 0.30.7 - with the "Hide photos already imported" feature.

* Set timezone to some location using `ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/something/somewhere /etc/localtime`
* Import a bunch of pictures into Shotwell from and SD card
* Change the timezone by linking `/etc/localtime` to some other location with a different time zone
* Notice how the already imported pictures on this SD are shown again by Shotwell, even with "Hide photos already imported" checked.

Let me know if I can clarify this further or if this deserves a separate issue being created.

note.body:
It turns out it is possible to achieve the desired behavior just by [modifying the check][check]. It raises a few questions though. If secrets should be hidden when searching all items, should they be hidden when searching specific attributes as well? It would probably break scripts to change the existing output, but it feels weird to have a flag that only applies when searching without attributes.

Also, should empty attribute lists be allowed for lookup? It doesn't seem particularly useful, but it would be more consistent. What about clear and store, which seem more dangerous to allow empty attribute lists for?

[check]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/grantmoyer/libsecret/commit/fd55c157298fc95a0dbabb5eeadb9bebadb02ee9

My work situation has recently changed and I know that I would greatly benefit from seeing Wayland have native RDP support (and probably many others would, too)

This is what I do:

1. Paste the data into Gnumeric so it fills A1-A73.
2. Choose from menu "Statistics > Descriptive Statistics > Frequency Tables > Histogram"
3. Set
 - Input range: Sheet1!$A$1:$A$73
 - Grouped by: Columns (the default)
 - Cutoff: Calculated cutoffs (the default), Number of cutoffs 22
 - Defaults for everything else (includes "Histogram chart" option in Graphs & Options)

Even if I don't change anything in (3), so the number of cutoffs stays at 12, the same problem is observed, but the wrong scaling in the graph is different. With 22 cutoffs, it looks as if the count was divided by 6, while with 12 cutoffs, it looks as if the count was divided by 11.5.

events.target_title: Duplicate artist entries

note.body:
Hello again! I sent you the requested email.

However, when trying to narrow down the files to send, I have come to new insights that shed more light at the issue:

I realised that the particular tag `isrc` actually has no specific relevance to the disappearance of the behaviour. Rather, the fact that I re-write the tags using the exfalso software does: I can do any kind of edit and re-save in exfalso to fix the duplicate artist problem.

---

So apparently, the way Musicbrainz Picard saves the tags with it's default settings (ID3v2 2.3, UTF-16), does in some rare cases throw off Lollypop's artist categorisation.

Maybe it has something to do with the encoding. Or that there is some invisible extra control character thrown in that Lollypop does not strip off.

When I set Picard to save ID3v2 in 2.4 format with UTF-8, Lollypop does NOT show the artist duplication behaviour.

---

I hope you have an easy time identifying what the format discrepancies actually boil down to with this information and the test files.

events.target_title: Duplicate artist entries

note.body:
Dependent on what you find out:

Possibly we may actually identify a bug in the way Picard formats its IDv3 2.3 tags?

To verify that it is not a bug that has already been fixed in newer version of Picard, I tested with their latest version 2.1.3: IDv3 2.3-tagged files saved with that version still trigger the erroneous behaviour in Lollypop.

I also searched open issues at https://tickets.metabrainz.org/projects/PICARD/issues, but I could not correlate any open ID3v2.3 issues to something that could trigger the erroneous behaviour in Lollypop.

events.target_title: Duplicate artist entries

note.body:
Hm, interesting!

So using your approach above I could see that the full URL behaviour only happens in the Picard id3v2.3 version. The "Neon Golden" album seems to be the "full URL"-culprit in this example.

When viewing any of the file versions of "Neon Golden" with mutagen's `mid3v2` I get the following:

```
mid3v2 The\ Notwist\ \(2002\)\ Neon\ Golden/01\ One\ Step\ Inside\ Doesn\'t\ Mean\ You\ Understand.mp3
[...]
TXXX=MusicBrainz Album Artist Id=f180cec2-9421-4417-a841-c7372090d13d
TXXX=MusicBrainz Album Id=3516141a-f331-4f94-a570-e06b2c50e700
TXXX=MusicBrainz Album Release Country=XE
TXXX=MusicBrainz Album Status=official
TXXX=MusicBrainz Album Type=album
TXXX=MusicBrainz Artist Id=f180cec2-9421-4417-a841-c7372090d13d
TXXX=MusicBrainz Release Group Id=7e0c1da0-f2b6-3d5a-93b1-c96c1da15fca
[...]
TXXX=musicbrainz_albumartistid=http://musicbrainz.org/artist/f180cec2-9421-4417-a841-c7372090d13d
TXXX=musicbrainz_albumid=http://musicbrainz.org/release/0e9c6c79-02b7-4111-8c86-e1b173572113.html
TXXX=musicbrainz_artistid=http://musicbrainz.org/artist/f180cec2-9421-4417-a841-c7372090d13d
```

So there are two sets of Musicbrainz tags, of which the `musicbrainz_albumartistid` one contains the full URL, but the `MusicBrainz Artist Id` does not.

Both sets of tags are unchanged between the id3v2.4 and id3v2.3 versions. (Exfalso seems to save tags in id3v2.4 as well.)

So it turns out not to be a bug in Picard after all, since I did tell it not to touch any older tags the file may contain.

What it does looks like though, is that Lollypop has different priorities as to which tag to select for reading the Musicbrainz artist id, depending on the id3v2 version.

One could argue that this is inconsistent behaviour in Lollypop. But I would understand if you were of the opinion that this duplicate tags situation is too narrow a corner case to be worth your development time.

Personally, I am happy with the solution of fixing the tags in my files. Probably by enabling the *Clear existing tags* option under the "Tags" section in the Picard Options when re-tagging.

Thank you very much for all your help and effort, Cédric, and especially for creating the great piece of software that Lollypop is!

events.target_title: The Authenticator does not want to restore the json file from the backup

note.body:
Hey, I've got a fix for this.
find out if you have a system or user install.
if its a system install, you need to go to `/var/lib/flatpak/app/com.github.bilelmoussaoui.Authenticator/x86_64/stable/...huge jumble of letters.../files/lib/python3.7/site-packages/Authenticator/models`.

else you need to go to `~/.local/share/flatpak/app/com.github.bilelmoussaoui.Authenticator/x86_64/stable/...huge jumble of letters.../files/lib/python3.7/site-packages/Authenticator/models`.

Then, open the backup.py file and change line 32 from
```python
        from ..widgets.accounts import AccountsWidget
```
to
```python
        from ..widgets.accounts.list import AccountsWidget
```

you may need to do things differently as per your platform.
This fixed it for me.
